bunpro.writeup: Likeことがある,ことができるis an expression that nominalizes what comes before it (turns it into a noun-phrase), and then highlights something about that (A) phrase. In the case ofことができる, the thing being highlighted about (A) is that it is 'possible'. This translates as 'can do (A)', or 'to be able to do (A)'.However,ことis only required when the (A) phrase needs nominalization (is not a noun to begin with). Due to this,ができるmay be used by itself when following a noun, without changing the meaning.Fun Factのが(orのは) is also frequently used for nominalization, but this is rarely the case when a verb follows it. Some other expressions whereのがmay not be swapped forことare as follows:ことがある - For (A) to exist.ことにする - To make something (A).ことになる - For (A) to come to be.

examples.japanese: 魚のように泳ぐことができるように毎日練習する。
examples.english: I practice everyday so that I will be able to swim like a fish.

examples.japanese: 彼は料理をすることができる。
運転ができる彼氏が欲しい。
examples.english: I want a boyfriend that can drive.

examples.japanese: 力仕事ができる人を探しています。
examples.english: We are looking for a person that is able to do physical labor.

examples.japanese: 初めて、漢字を書く事が出来た。
examples.english: I was able to write kanji for the first time.

examples.japanese: 私の子供は一人で買い物が出来る。
examples.english: My kid can go shopping by himself.

examples.japanese: 私の姉は歌う事が出来る。

dojg.grammar_point: ことが出来る・できる

examples.japanese: (ks).田口さんは中国語を話すことが出来る・出来ます。
(a).新幹線に乗れば大阪まで三時間で行くことが出来る。
examples.english: If you take the bullet train, you can get to Osaka in three hours.

examples.japanese: (b).小田さんは六つの時バッハを弾くことが出来た。
examples.english: Oda was able to play Bach at the age of six.

examples.japanese: (c).ジョンソンさんは日本語で手紙を書くことが出来る。
examples.english: Mr. Johnson can write letters in Japanese.
